docs.lead_paragraph: Some Alzheimer’s patients who used the therapy, already approved for immune disorders, showed no worsening of symptoms for three years.

headline.seo: Trial Hints Baxter’s Gammagard Can Slow Alzheimer’s
headline.main: Small Trial Hints Drug Can Slow Alzheimer’s
headline.print_headline: Small Trial Hints Drug Can Slow Alzheimer’s

docs.abstract: Results of a small study show that a drug already on the market to treat immune disorders may help stabilize patients with Alzheimer's disease for up to three years; four patients received doses of Gammagard from Baxter International and had no decline in several measures of cognition and daily function over the course of the study; experts say that results are not conclusive and that the drug may not be responsible for the stabilization; further trials are planned.
docs.snippet: Some Alzheimer’s patients who used the therapy, already approved for immune disorders, showed no worsening of symptoms for three years.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's one of those secrets you normally don't learn in nursing school: ''Don't go to the hospital in July.'' That's the month when medical residents, newly graduated from medical school, start learning how to be doctors, and they learn by taking care of patients. And learning means making mistakes. There's disagreement in the medical literature about whether a so-called July Effect, where medical error rates increase in the summer, actually exists. But a 2010 article in the Journal of General Internal Medicine and a 2011 article in the Annals of Internal Medicine both found evidence of it. In an interview, Dr. John Q. Young, lead author of the latter review, likened the deployment of new residents to having rookies replace seasoned football players during ''a high-stakes game, and in the middle of that final drive.''
docs.abstract: Bedside column by oncology nurse Theresa Brown highlights the problem of the so-called July Effect in hospitals, in which the adequacy and quality of medical care is affected by an influx of new medical school graduates; contends that in many cases, new doctors know less than experienced nurses, and to address the problem there needs to be better supervision of new doctors by senior residents, fellows and attending physicians, as well as by nurses. Drawing (M)
